Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: IDBR Type A: QSTORM-AO - Wavefront-shaping light-sheet microscopy with photoswitchable quantum dots for superresolution imaging in thick tissue
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of Georgia to develop a novel super-resolution microscope for biological research. For students and early-career researchers, this close collaboration at the intersection of biology, physics, optics, and chemical engineering will provide an invaluable training experience, and it will be enriched with professional development in interdisciplinary science communication skills. All team members will contribute to the development of an online team blog, lab notebook, and public website that will capture the progress of the research within a broader historical, scientific, and visual context, curated by the Boston Museum of Science. The Museum of Science team will also disseminate this work to thousands of science museum visitors, students, and the broader community with live presentations, demonstrations, podcasts, and a short NOVA-style film on the quest to see more clearly and deeply into the mysteries of life. The film will be directed by a multiple award-winning NOVA producer.

This instrument will combine holographic imaging using high resolution spatial light modulators and new techniques for correcting distortion induced by light scattering in thick biological tissue to achieve molecular-scale resolution inside organisms important for modern biological research, such as fruit flies and zebrafish. At The Ohio State University, semiconductor nanotechnology will be combined with DNA origami to create intensely bright and switchable light emitters, individually targetable to selected molecules operating within biological systems. This novel combination of high-precision technologies will provide investigators an unprecedented view of important subcellular biological processes, such as neuronal signaling in intact organisms, potentially contributing to breakthroughs in areas of molecular and systems biology, biological engineering, medicine, and human health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Strategic Projects team at the Museum of Science, led by PI Carol Lynn Alpert, collaborated with the chemical engineering team led by Jessica O. Winter at The Ohio State University (award #1555470) and the optics team led by Peter Kner at the University of Georgia (award #1555576) to pursue several breakthroughs in biological imaging by using engineering light sources known as Quantum dots and a superresolution imaging strategy known as STORM, applying light sheet and adaptive optics. The Museum team's roles in the collaboration were the following:

1. Coordinate and facilitate cross-disciplinary communication among the research teams.

2. Provide guidance in science communication to the researchers and their students.

3. Share the story of this ongoing research project with broad public audiences.

4. Create and produce a website that would serve as a joint record of the work of the teams and meetings, provide experience for the trainees in science communication, and open a window for public audiences to learn about the science and engineering issues and also about the actual day-to-day practice of cross-disciplinary research.

5. Produce a film about instrument and infrastructure development for biological research.

Outcomes for each:

1. MOS PI Carol Lynn Alpert coordinated and moderated monthly phone and zoom meetings from 2015 to 2021.  Each was summarized in a blog post on qstorm.org with visuals.

2. Alpert guided the graduate students, postdocs, and undergraduate students in submitting monthly lab reports in the team blog. The researchers and students also worked with the Museum team in making public presentations, podcasts, and visitor activities at the Museum of Science, the Carnegie Science Center, and COSI in Columbus.

3. The MOS team created a lively 20-minute museum stage presentation, called "Making Molecular Movies with QSTORM," that explained the quest, as well as the science and engineering involved, for family audiences.  The presentation was enhanced with superb visualizations, animations, and analogies, and props such as real quantum dots and full-size cardboard cutouts of the researchers to enhance the telling of how their individual motivations and skills were joined together in a team-science, cross-disciplinary quest that could advance biological research.  This presentation was delivered 352 times in Boston to audiences totalling 13,230.  It was also delivered at the Carnegie Science Center and COSI and packaged and disseminated to other museums through the Nanoscale Informal Science Education Network.  A video was made of the presentation, and posted to YouTube at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X5FGu4qkfhw.  That video has been viewed over 1,300 times.  In addition, OSU PI Jessica Winter delivered two guest presentations at the Museum, about her quest to also apply quantum dot engineering to improving cancer diagnosis. This video is also posted on the QSTORM playlist at https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLHlDljovBPle1nvJV6kCsRqbsBvC5m6ru, along with other videos and animations about QSTORM and podcasts with three of the other QSTORM researchers.  Two wonderful animations were made about the team's efforts through a collaboration with seniors at the New England Institute of Art.  The MOS team also developed several hands-on demos to introduce quantum dots and safely demonstrate their luminescence. 

4. www.qstorm.org was created in 2017 and succeeded the qstormlegacy.org website which chronicled the efforts of the larger team of researchers who worked on this project 2010-2015.  All PIs and students contributed to the development of the site, providing friendly team bios, visuals, monthly lab reports (in the form of blog posts), and listing their publications.  The website now contains 108 blog posts chronicling the research between 2015 and 2021.  Meetings and posts continued during the COVID-19 pandemic, even when researchers were locked out of their labs.  The site lists (with links to most) 37 publications, 47 conference presentations, 10 posters, and two invention disclosures produced by QSTORM team members during this time period, and links to five video presentations and three podcasts suitable for public audiences, and five video presentations for professional audiences.  The MOS team itself delivered 2 papers, 14 conference presentations, 3 posters, 13 videos and podcasts, and a documentary film.

5. THE BRAIN MAPPERS, a 31-minute documentary film produced by multiple Emmy-award winning NOVA producer Larry Klein was completed in July 2021.  The film chronicles the efforts of teams around the country collaborating to make breakthroughs in connectomics - the mapping of the neural circuitry of a brain at synapse-level detail.  The effort involves neuroscientists, biologists, electron microscopists, and AI/machine learning specialists. The film is posted at www.mos.org/brainmappers.  A 1-minute video promo and an 80-second version were also produced to aid in distribution.  The NSF Center for Brains, Minds, and Machines (award #1231216) contributed knowledge and resources.

In many respects, the Museum of Science team surpassed expectations for its participation in the collaborative QSTORM-AO initiative: helping to unite the research teams in their efforts, providing professional development in science communication, and bringing a dynamic story of cutting-edge team science to thousands.
